result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Jerry E. Willey was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Forthwith
Consecutive to: to any other sentence

superMiscConds.notes: Provide DNA sample.  Undergo any counseling/treatment per agent.  Not to operate m/v w/o valid DL.  Not to possess controlled substances w/o valid prescription and must notify agent w/in 48 hours if one is received.  Not to go to taverns/bars or business where primary purpose of business is sale of alcohol or drug paraphernalia.  Absolute Sobriety.

If probation/extended supervision revoked or discharges with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Jerry E. Willey in court with attorney Misty M. Muter.  Defendant Jerry E. Willey in custody.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State states case and appearances.  State states DE will waive prelim today and proceed to plea/sent today.  State states recs.  Atty Muter agrees and states DE will waive prelim.  DE agrees.  Court questions DE on prelim waiver/accepts/finds probable cause and binds over.  Atty Muter acknowledges rec. information, waives reading and pleads NC to Ct 1.  DE agrees.  Court questions DE on plea/accepts/finds guilty.  State makes statement.  Any jail credit would be stipulated to at a later time.  Atty Muter makes statement.  Court questions DE re: right to have a PSI completed.  DE waives right to PSI.  Court accepts waiver of PSI.  DE makes statement on his own behalf.  State says they are concerned because it sounds like the DE is arguing against his own plea agreement but they will proceed today.  Atty Muter agrees to proceed, as does DE.  Court admonishes DE and sentences.  DE advised of voting rights, felony firearms warngins and voting rights.

Ct 1:  NC
3 years prison (1 year initial confinement + 2 years extended supervision) consecutive to any other sentence to commence FORTHWITH
$1479.00 fine/costs/surcharges and $25.00 blood draw fee to be paid per agent
Revoke DL 36 months
IID for 36 months
AODA
Conditions of extended supervision:
Absolute sobriety at all times
Not to go to bars/taverns/liquor stores
Not to operate MV w/o valid DL
Any other conditions per agent
DNA sample to be provided unless one has previously been provided
DE is eligible for ERP/SAP but not eligible for CIP due to age

Ct 2:  Dismissed
Ct 3:  Dismissed
Plea/sentencing hearing on March 12, 2015 at 09:00 am.

Court finds good cause to extend the time for holding the preliminary hearing.  Bond continues.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for December 3, 2014 at 11:00 am.

Defendant Jerry E. Willey by video from LEC with attorney Thomas L. Steinman.  Defendant Jerry E. Willey in custody.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant waives reading of complaint.  DE hasn't applie for PD appt yet.  State requests cash bond.  Atty Steinman responds.  Advised rights to an attorney.  Requests Preliminary hearing; Time limits NOT waived.  $2,500.00 cash bond set.  Special bond conditions as follows:  Absolute sobriety at all times, not to operate MV w/o valid DL, must submit to tests if requested to do so by law enforcement and not to go to bars/taverns/liquor stores.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for November 21, 2014 at 11:15 am.
